text:
Bucket list for a visitor to South Africa Published on : Monday, September 7, 2015
Yes, it is spring, that time of the year that the start of the travel industry’s biggest month, Tourism Month. September 27 is World Tourism Day, highlighting and celebrating the importance of the industry in creating jobs and helping build sustainable societies.
This international day’s theme for 2015 is ‘1 Billion Tourists, 1 Billion Opportunities’, and it’s a global pact geared to encourage local citizens to get out and experience their cities like tourists and support the domestic economy, something that Cape Town Tourism has been promoting for many years through campaigns like My Cape Town.
For the South African travel industry, this month is also an occasion to celebrate its own Heritage Day and for members of the public to keep abreast of Rugby World Cup activity.
For those unsure of what to see and do this month, Cape Town Tourism has created the ultimate Cape Town bucket list. Highlighting 100 fantastic things to do in Cape Town.
Here are some of the things you can do in Cape Town this month…
SANParks Week
SANParks Week takes place from 14 – 19 September and offers free entrance to most of the Table Mountain National Park pay points (excluding Boulders Penguin Colony and the Table Mountain Cableway).
ABSA Boktown
For all those rugby fans keen to enjoy the Rugby World Cup, the V&A Waterfront will transform its amphitheatre into the ABSA Boktown from 19 Sept – 31 Oct 2015.
Broadcasting all the Bokke games live, the venue will be open to the public for free (seats are limited to 500).
Cape Town Marathon
Also on the sporting front, on 20 September Capetonians and visitors from all over will be taking part in the Cape Town Marathon. Runners will be able to take in the sights and sounds of the city in all of its natural beauty on this 42.2km run.
Kirstenbosch Garden Tour
And for nature lovers, there’s a wonderful opportunity to take advantage of a free garden tour at Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden from 22 – 27 September. The 2-hour tours will be conducted by professional guides every day from 10:00 – 14:00 and will focus on this United Nations Educational Scientific Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) heritage site.
Khayelitsha Arts Festival
For a true immersive experience in local culture, the Khayelitsha Arts Festival (24 – 27 September) offers all the opportunity to engage with the close-knit Khayelitsha community and allows locals to showcase the best they have to offer the world.
Fringe Arts Festival
The Fringe Arts Festival (24 September – 4 October), taking place in the CBD and Langa, returns to the Mother City for a second year with 80 performances including dance, theatre, family performances and more.
Good Night Market
The Good Night Market held on the last Wednesday of the month (30 September) at the Watershed in the V&A Waterfront is an exciting and trendy way to end the month.
